editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Warden and Fellows of Merton College .

msContents.summary: MS 1 is in many ways the classic Merton College medieval book. Made commercially, probably in Oxford, it was given to the College by the noted theologian and fellow Thomas Buckingham, some time in the second quarter of the 14th century; he may have been its first owner. It appears in a list of the College’s theological books made in 1349 and retains its College binding of the late 15th century. It contains an impressive collection of the works of Augustine, the most popular author in the library. Despite its high value and considerable weight, this book seems to have been in circulation among the fellows rather than chained in the library room.

msItem.note: On the front pastedown is a table of contents, in an anglicana hand not much later than the main text, annotated in one or more hands of s. xvi.

msItem.note: The text ends half-way down col. 1; it appears that text on the rest of the leaf has been erased. The next art. begins about a quarter of the way down f. 347v col. a. CPL 326; CCSL 49 (1985), pp. 35–125 line 1158.

msItem.title: De Honestate Mulierum (Serm. app. 293)

msItem.author: Ps.-Augustine
msItem.title: De Visitatione Infirmorum
msItem.incipit: Visitacionis sacra Nepoti meo carissimo morienti

msItem.author: Augustine
msItem.title: Epist. 166
msItem.incipit: Deum nostrum qui uocauit in regnum suum

msItem.author: Guigo of Chartreux
msItem.title: Epistola ad Durbones Fratres super Epistolas S. Hieronymi (ep. 4)
msItem.rubric: Incipit epistola GuidonisGuigonis prioris Cartusie ad Durbones fratres super epistolas beati Ieronimi
msItem.incipit: Amicis et fratribus in Christo dilectissimis Lazaro Durbonensi priori
msItem.explicit: in principio collocate. Valete orate pro nobis
msItem.note: ed. J. Mabillon, Annales Ordinis S. Benedicti (Paris, 1703), I, p. 331.
On f. 368 is a table of contents, s. xvii.

supportDesc.extent:
370 leaves (1–368, incl. 15A, 70A) 410 255
330–45 180–90
The edges heavily retrimmed affecting running heads and marginalia, and stained yellow.
supportDesc.collation: A pastedown (possibly the first leaf of an original bifolium), a bifolium, excised, 1–212, 38, 412, 514, 6–2912, 3012(12 canc.; 3 additional bifolia wrapped round the outside of the quire), 316, a bifolium, the second leaf a pastedown; catchwords and leaf-numbers.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled with crayon in 2 cols of 78–80 lines. Running heads between ruled lines.

handDesc.handNote: Written in a single expert gothic rotunda bookhand of French appearance, except for ff. 345–7, and 358–67v, in a single anglicana hand which annotates throughout. This may be the hand of Thomas Buckingham (see below).

decoDesc.decoNote: Handsome vinet initials in blue, pink, orange and gold, sometimes with partial borders, open arts 6–10, and bks 5–9 of 6; red and blue initials flourished in red and violet; blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs; early on running heads in red and blue capitals; red highlighting, underlining and framing of marginal chapter-numbers.

binding.p: s. xv ex., tawed skin over reverse-bevelled oak boards with projecting squares, sewn on eight bands, raised on the spine; blue and plain endbands; two broad leather straps with brass clasps, the uppermost now gone, from recesses in the front board to catches in the back, the lower catch gone. Marks of brass chain-staples at the foredge of the front board near head and foot. At the bottom outer corner of f. 1 are rust marks from another chain-staple, probably from the foredge. At the foot of the rear pastedown, near the spine, is a mark perhaps from another brass chain-staple.

history.provenance: Probably made commercially in Oxford. An inscription may have been on one of the two or three leaves at the front now excised.

The secundo folio identifies it as UO47. 197 (1349), the gift of Thomas of Buckingham (BRUO 298–9), fellow by 1324, gone 1338 × 1340, d. 1347 × 1353. He also gave UO47. 166, no longer extant, and to Exeter Cathedral Bodl. Libr., Bodl. 335.
On f. 368 are two thoroughly erased inscriptions, probably cautiones since the second is accompanied by a stationer’s mark.

On f. 368v a third erased inscription can be partially read: ‘Caucio M. Walteri de Burtone exposita in cista Warwik anno Domini M. trescesima in sescentesima prima.’ Walter de Burton (BRUO 321) occ. as fellow of Merton in 1312, until 1328, still alive in late 1334, prob. d. by April 1335.

On the front pastedown are: ‘Li iius’, s. xv, showing that the book was then part of a College electio; ‘N. 1. 1. Art:’, s. xvii, canc. and replaced with ‘A. 2. 1’ twice, in purple ink, s. xix; near the head, ‘M. A. 5’, s. xvii; modern ‘No I.’ in red; ‘Liber Coll. Merton.’, s. xvii or xviii; the remains of the College bookplate.
On f. 368v, perhaps s. xviii, ‘Hosoboby’ or ‘J. Cosoboby’ and ‘Augustinus / Mert. Coll.’

source.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Merton College, Oxford (Cambridge: D. S. Brewer), 2009.

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact Merton College Library.
